lines.text: P = power, W = work, ∆E = energy transfer, ∆t = elapsed time

secText: Light bulbs are often described in terms of their power consumption.  Their power rating, in watts, describes how many joules of electrical energy are turned into heat and light every second. In a 100-watt (100 W) bulb, 100 joules of electrical energy become heat and light every second.
One equation for power is the same as the definition − energy divided by time, which is to say the rate of energy transfer.

We can also relate power to work. Power is the rate at which work is done: the work done divided by the elapsed time time.   For instance, if 200 joules of work is done on a system at a constant rate over 5 seconds, the power is 200 divided by 5, which is to say 40 watts.
The unit for power is the watt. One watt is one joule per second.
